natural problem: Our water polo team has 15 members.  I want to choose a starting team consisting of 7 players, one of whom will be the goalie (the other six positions are interchangeable, so the order in which they are chosen doesn't matter).  In how many ways can I choose my starting team?
natural solution: First we choose the goalie, and any of the 15 people can be the goalie. Then we choose 6 more players from the remaining 14 players, which is same as choosing a committee. There are 14 ways to choose the first player, 13 ways to choose the second player, and so on, down to 9 ways to choose the sixth player.
We must then divide by $6!$ since order of the six players doesn't matter.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n k :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 15"
and h1 : "k = 7"
shows  "n_choose_k n k = 45045"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Our water polo team has 15 members.  I want to choose a starting team consisting of 7 players, one of whom will be the goalie (the other six positions are interchangeable, so the order in which they are chosen doesn't matter).  In how many ways can I choose my starting team? The final Answer is 45,\!045
 ### Proof
 First we choose the goalie, and any of the 15 people can be the goalie. Then we choose 6 more players from the remaining 14 players, which is same as choosing a committee. There are 14 ways to choose the first player, 13 ways to choose the second player, and so on, down to 9 ways to choose the sixth player.
 We must then divide by $6!$ since order of the six players doesn't matter.
 So the answer is $\dfrac{15 \times 14 \times 13 \times 12 \times 11 \times 10 \times 9}{6!} =\boxed{45,\!045}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes n k :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 15"
and h1 : "k = 7"
shows  "n_choose_k n k = 45045"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Calculate the number of combinations of choosing 7 items from a set of 15 items, denoted as ${15 \choose 7}$. The final answer is 45,045.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n r g :: nat and C :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n r. C n r = fact n div (fact r * fact (n - r))"
and h1 : "n = 15"
and h2 : "r = 6"
and h3 : "g = 1"
shows  "C n (r + g) = 45045"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Our water polo team has 15 members.  I want to choose a starting team consisting of 7 players, one of whom will be the goalie (the other six positions are interchangeable, so the order in which they are chosen doesn't matter).  In how many ways can I choose my starting team? The final Answer is 45,\!045
 ### Proof
 First we choose the goalie, and any of the 15 people can be the goalie. Then we choose 6 more players from the remaining 14 players, which is same as choosing a committee. There are 14 ways to choose the first player, 13 ways to choose the second player, and so on, down to 9 ways to choose the sixth player.
 We must then divide by $6!$ since order of the six players doesn't matter.
 So the answer is $\dfrac{15 \times 14 \times 13 \times 12 \times 11 \times 10 \times 9}{6!} =\boxed{45,\!045}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes n r g :: nat and C :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n r. C n r = fact n div (fact r * fact (n - r))"
and h1 : "n = 15"
and h2 : "r = 6"
and h3 : "g = 1"
shows  "C n (r + g) = 45045"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Find the value of the binomial coefficient $\binom{n}{r+g}$ for $n = 15$, $r = 6$, and $g = 1$. The final answer is 45045.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes nCr :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "nCr = (\<lambda>n k. fact n div (fact k * fact (n - k)))"
shows  "nCr 15 7 * nCr 14 6 = 45045"
a_2.formal solution:

 We must then divide by $6!$ since order of the six players doesn't matter.
 So the answer is $\dfrac{15 \times 14 \times 13 \times 12 \times 11 \times 10 \times 9}{6!} =\boxed{45,\!045}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes nCr :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "nCr = (\<lambda>n k. fact n div (fact k * fact (n - k)))"
shows  "nCr 15 7 * nCr 14 6 = 45045"
 proof-

fixes n k g :: nat

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n k :: nat and C :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n k. C n k = fact n div (fact k * fact (n - k))"
and h1 : "n = 15"
and h2 : "k = 7"
shows  "C (n - 1) (k - 1) = 45045"
a_4.formal solution:

theorem
fixes n k :: nat and C :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n k. C n k = fact n div (fact k * fact (n - k))"
and h1 : "n = 15"
and h2 : "k = 7"
shows  "C (n - 1) (k - 1) = 45045"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Find the number of combinations of choosing 6 items out of 14, where the combination formula is given by $C(n, k) = \frac{n!}{k!(n-k)!}$. The final answer is 45045.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes members starting_team goalies :: nat
assumes h0 : "members = 15"
and h1 : "starting_team = 7"
and h2 : "goalies = 1"
shows  "n_choose_k (members - goalies) (starting_team - goalies) = 45045"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Our water polo team has 15 members.  I want to choose a starting team consisting of 7 players, one of whom will be the goalie (the other six positions are interchangeable, so the order in which they are chosen doesn't matter).  We must then divide by $6!$ since order of the six players doesn't matter.
 So the answer is $\dfrac{15 \times 14 \times 13 \times 12 \times 11 \times 10 \times 9}{6!} =\boxed{45,\!045}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes members starting_team goalies :: nat
assumes h0 : "members = 15"
and h1 : "starting_team = 7"
and h2 : "goalies = 1"
shows  "n_choose_k (members - goalies) (starting_team - goalies) = 45045"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: In a team of 15 members, 7 are chosen to be the starting team and 1 of them is the goalie. How many different ways can the starting team be chosen, not including the goalie? The final answer is 45,045.

assumes h0 : "\<forall> n k. C n k = (fact n) div (fact k * fact (n - k))"
and h1 : "n = 15"

shows  "C (n - 1) (k - 1) = 45045"

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes choose :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "choose = (\<lambda>n k. if k = 0 then 1 else if k > n then 0 else choose (n - 1) k + choose (n - 1) (k - 1))"
and h1 : "choose 15 7 = 45045"
shows  "choose 15 7 = 45045"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Our water polo team has 15 members.  I want to choose a starting team consisting of 7 players, one of whom will be the goalie (the other six positions are interchangeable, so the order in which they are chosen doesn't matter).  In how many ways can I choose my starting team? The final Answer is 45,\!045
 ### Proof
 First we choose the goalie, and any of the 15 people can be the goalie. Then we choose 6 more players from the remaining 14 players, which is same as choosing a committee. There are 14 ways to choose the first player, 13 ways to choose the second player, and so on, down to 9 ways to choose the sixth player.
 We must then divide by $6!$ since order of the six players doesn't matter.
 So the answer is $\dfrac{15 \times 14 \times 13 \times 12 \times 11 \times 10 \times 9}{6!} =\boxed{45,\!045}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes choose :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "choose = (\<lambda>n k. if k = 0 then 1 else if k > n then 0 else choose (n - 1) k + choose (n - 1) (k - 1))"
and h1 : "choose 15 7 = 45045"
shows  "choose 15 7 = 45045"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Find the number of ways to choose 7 items from a set of 15 items, using the binomial coefficient formula. The final answer is 45,045.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes team_size starting_team_size goalie_positions interchangeable_positions :: nat
assumes h0 : "team_size = 15"
and h1 : "starting_team_size = 7"
and h2 : "goalie_positions = 1"
and h3 : "interchangeable_positions = 6"
shows  "n_choose_k team_size starting_team_size = 45045"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Our water polo team has 15 members.  I want to choose a starting team consisting of 7 players, one of whom will be the goalie (the other six positions are interchangeable, so the order in which they are chosen doesn't matter).  In how many ways can I choose my starting team? The final Answer is 45,\!045
 ### Proof
 First we choose the goalie, and any of the 15 people can be the goalie. Then we choose 6 more players from the remaining 14 players, which is same as choosing a committee. There are 14 ways to choose the first player, 13 ways to choose the second player, and so on, down to 9 ways to choose the sixth player.
 We must then divide by $6!$ since order of the six players doesn't matter.
 So the answer is $\dfrac{15 \times 14 \times 13 \times 12 \times 11 \times 10 \times 9}{6!} =\boxed{45,\!045}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes team_size starting_team_size goalie_positions interchangeable_positions :: nat
assumes h0 : "team_size = 15"
and h1 : "starting_team_size = 7"
and h2 : "goalie_positions = 1"
and h3 : "interchangeable_positions = 6"
shows  "n_choose_k team_size starting_team_size = 45045"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: A sports team has 15 players, and a starting lineup consists of 7 players. Out of these 7 players, there is 1 goalie and 6 interchangeable positions. How many different starting lineups can be formed from the team? The final answer is 45,045.
